0jwWfOt1afXnhaiYYgnQ.title: Supreme Court throws out appellate rulings in favor of transgender people in 4 states
0jwWfOt1afXnhaiYYgnQ.content:
[img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Supreme-Court-throws.webp" caption="FILE - Transgenders rights supporters rally outside of the Supreme Court in Washington."]
The Supreme Court on Monday threw out appellate rulings in favor of transgender people in four states following the justices' recent decision upholding a Tennessee ban on certain medical treatment for transgender youths.

But the justices took no action in cases from Arizona, Idaho and West Virginia involving the participation of transgender students on school sports teams. The court could say as soon as Thursday whether it will take up the issue in its next term.

The high court ordered appellate judges to reexamine cases from Idaho, North Carolina, Oklahoma and West Virginia involving access to medical care and birth certificates.

The action was unsurprising because the court had set the cases aside until after it decided the Tennessee case, as typically happens when the same legal issue is being considered.

The rulings all included findings that the restrictions on transgender people imposed by the states violate the Constitution's equal protection clause.

In the Tennessee case, the Supreme Court ruled that there was no constitutional violation in a state law prohibiting puberty blockers and hormone therapy to treat gender dysphoria in people younger than 18.

The justices ordered the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Richmond, Virginia, to review its decision that West Virginia‚Äôs and North Carolina‚Äôs refusal to cover certain health care for transgender people with government-sponsored insurance is discriminatory.

The San Francisco-based 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals will get back a case from Idaho stemming from the state's ban on certain surgical procedures for Medicaid recipients.

The 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Denver will review its ruling blocking an Oklahoma ban on people changing their gender on birth certificates.

In one other case, from Kentucky, the justices rejected the appeal of transgender minors and their families challenging that state‚Äôs ban on gender-affirming care.

6kedlLilTQ3FMLjabzh7.title: Immigrants disappear from US detainee tracking system after deportation flights
6kedlLilTQ3FMLjabzh7.content: [img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Immigrants-disappear-from.webp" caption="This undated photo provided by Johanny Sanchez shows Sanchez, right, and her husband Franco Caraballo, who was sent over the weekend to El Salvador accused by the Trump administration of belonging to the Venezuelan Tren de Aragua gang."] Franco Caraballo called his wife Friday night, crying and panicked. Hours earlier, the 26-year-old barber and dozens of other Venezuelan migrants at a federal detention facility in Texas were dressed in white clothes, handcuffed and taken onto a plane. He had no idea where he was going. Twenty-four hours later, Caraballo‚Äôs name disappeared from the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement‚Äôs online detainee locator. On Monday, his wife, Johanny S√°nchez, learned Caraballo was among more than 200 Venezuelan immigrants flown over the weekend to El Salvador, where they are in a maximum-security prison after being accused by the Trump administration of belonging to the Venezuelan Tren de Aragua gang. S√°nchez insists her husband isn't a gang member. She struggles even to find logic in the accusation. The weekend flights Flights by U.S. immigration authorities set off a frantic scramble among terrified families after hundreds of immigrants vanished from ICE‚Äôs online locator. Some turned up at that massive El Salvador prison, where visitors, recreation and education are not allowed. The U.S. has paid El Salvador's government $6 million to hold immigrants, many of them Venezuelan, whose government rarely accepts deportees from the U.S. But many families have no idea where to find their loved ones. El Salvador has no online database to look up inmates, and families there often struggle to get information. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know anything about my son,‚Äù said Xiomara Vizcaya, a 46-year-old Venezuelan. On Saturday, President Donald Trump announced he had invoked the Alien Enemies Act of 1798, which allows the U.S. to deport noncitizens without any legal recourse, including rights to appear before an immigration or federal court judge. Many conservatives have cheered the deportations and the Trump administration for taking a hard stance on immigration. The Venezuelan government has called the flights ‚Äúkidnappings.‚Äù It urged its citizens living in the U.S. to return home and vowed get others back from El Salvador. But with diplomatic ties long broken between Venezuela and El Salvador, the prisoners have few advocates. The U.S. deportations exacerbate Venezuela‚Äôs immigration crisis by turning ‚Äúmigrants into geopolitical pawns,‚Äù said Oscar Murillo, head of the Venezuelan human rights group Provea. "There is a lack of transparency on the part of the U.S. and El Salvador regarding the status of deported individuals and the crimes for which they are being prosecuted.‚Äù S√°nchez is among those who believes the American dream has turned ugly. She wants to leave the U.S. once she finds her husband. ‚ÄúWe fled Venezuela for a better future. We never imagined things would be worse.‚Äù

74h1cwlA5prYXIHq0BT5.title: Volunteers use bullhorns and sirens to warn immigrants when ICE is in their area
74h1cwlA5prYXIHq0BT5.summary: The comments present a broad range of perspectives regarding immigration enforcement, particularly the actions of volunteers who warn undocumented immigrants of ICE operations. A majority of commentators express strong support for strict immigration control, advocating for the arrest and prosecution of those perceived to be aiding undocumented immigrants by warning them of ICE activities, viewing this as criminal conduct tantamount to obstruction of justice. Conversely, a minority of commenters argue for the compassion and rights of immigrants, suggesting that aiding those seeking better lives shouldn't be criminalized and is akin to exercising free speech.
74h1cwlA5prYXIHq0BT5.content:
[img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Volunteers-use-bullhorns.webp" caption="Ron Gochez, a teacher volunteering with Union del Barrio, an organization advocating for immigrant rights, is reflected in a side mirror as he searches for ICE activity in a neighborhood in Los Angeles."]
Just before dawn, 10 people met at a parking lot shared by a laundromat and coffee shop in South Central Los Angeles on what has become a daily mission: Look for immigration officers and warn people of their presence to try to prevent arrests. Bullhorns and sirens are ready for use. 

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs raza that‚Äôs been detained,‚Äù Ron Gochez, founder of Union del Barrio's Los Angeles chapter, said before they split up in five cars. ‚ÄúIt seems like there‚Äôs more activity now. Let‚Äôs keep a close eye out.‚Äù 

Working with other similar-size groups and using walkie-talkies, the Community Self-Defense Coalition, made up of more than 60 organizations, found nothing Thursday but appeared to have disrupted U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement operations earlier in the week. In Los Angeles and across the country, these tactics have been a thorn in ICE's side as it tries to carry out President Donald Trump's promise of mass deportations. 

Counter-ICE operations have had ‚Äúa huge impact,‚Äù said John Fabbricatore, a former head of ICE's enforcement and removal division in Denver. 

‚ÄúIt's dangerous for the officers because they are trying to get into a situation, maybe undercover, trying to make an arrest without alarming the neighborhood, and then these guys come out here with these bullhorns and they start yelling and screaming,‚Äù Fabbricatore said. 

Advocates ‚Äúgo right to the edge‚Äù of a law against impeding federal law enforcement to avoid criminal prosecution, he said. 

Advocates say they are exercising free speech and reminding people of their rights. ICE officers cannot forcibly enter a home without a judicial warrant, which they rarely have. Sophisticated ‚Äúknow-your- rights‚Äù campaigns urge people to stay inside and not open the door. 

Back at the parking lot about two hours after Thursday's mission started, the city was waking up. On the corner, a street vendor had set up her tamales stand. 

‚ÄúWe just got a report right now that all of our patrols happening in San Diego, Escondido, California; Los Angeles, California; South Gate and Alhambra, everything is all clear right now,‚Äù said Gochez, before heading to his day job as a high school history teacher.

83JiUj8L8AZviu0LYcGq.title: Supreme Court throws out appellate rulings in favor of transgender people in 4 states
83JiUj8L8AZviu0LYcGq.content:
[img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Supreme-Court-throws.webp" caption="FILE - Transgenders rights supporters rally outside of the Supreme Court in Washington."]
The Supreme Court on Monday threw out appellate rulings in favor of transgender people in four states following the justices' recent decision upholding a Tennessee ban on certain medical treatment for transgender youths.

But the justices took no action in cases from Arizona, Idaho and West Virginia involving the participation of transgender students on school sports teams. The court could say as soon as Thursday whether it will take up the issue in its next term.

The high court ordered appellate judges to reexamine cases from Idaho, North Carolina, Oklahoma and West Virginia involving access to medical care and birth certificates.

The action was unsurprising because the court had set the cases aside until after it decided the Tennessee case, as typically happens when the same legal issue is being considered.

The rulings all included findings that the restrictions on transgender people imposed by the states violate the Constitution's equal protection clause.

In the Tennessee case, the Supreme Court ruled that there was no constitutional violation in a state law prohibiting puberty blockers and hormone therapy to treat gender dysphoria in people younger than 18.

The justices ordered the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Richmond, Virginia, to review its decision that West Virginia‚Äôs and North Carolina‚Äôs refusal to cover certain health care for transgender people with government-sponsored insurance is discriminatory.

The San Francisco-based 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals will get back a case from Idaho stemming from the state's ban on certain surgical procedures for Medicaid recipients.

The 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Denver will review its ruling blocking an Oklahoma ban on people changing their gender on birth certificates.

In one other case, from Kentucky, the justices rejected the appeal of transgender minors and their families challenging that state‚Äôs ban on gender-affirming care.

8d2wNb37QglGGLqiUq8W.title: How the military is dealing with Hegseth's order to remove transgender troops
8d2wNb37QglGGLqiUq8W.content:
[img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/How-the-military.webp" caption="Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth arrives before President Donald Trump speaks on his first 100 days at Macomb County Community College Sports Expo Center in Warren, Mich."]
The military services scrambled Friday to nail down details and put together new guidance to start removing transgender troops from the force.

Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, in a memo released late Thursday, reinstated orders issued earlier this year that said ‚Äúexpressing a false gender identity divergent from an individual's sex cannot satisfy the rigorous standards necessary for military service."

His new order gives active duty troops until June 6 to identify themselves as transgender and voluntarily begin to leave the service. National Guard and Reserve troops have until July 7.

Army Maj. Alivia Stehlik, who served in the infantry and is now a physical therapist, will be eligible to retire in three years but doesn‚Äôt want to be forced out for being a transgender service member.

‚ÄúI still have a job to do,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúMy command expects me to show up and be an officer and do my job because I‚Äôm the only person at my unit who can do what I do.‚Äù

The military services were rushing to put out new guidance to help commanders work through the process, including what to do in more complex situations, such as if any of the troops are deployed, at sea or may require special orders or funding to meet the deadlines.

There are about 2.1 million active duty, Guard and Reserve troops.

According to the Defense Department, about 1,000 service members have voluntarily identified themselves as transgender and will now begin the process of leaving the military. And while the totals are early estimates, as many as 500 of those are Army soldiers, hundreds are in the Navy and at least 50 are Marines.

CYyvocnTLWyU2vs6s8T6.title: How the military is dealing with Hegseth's order to remove transgender troops
CYyvocnTLWyU2vs6s8T6.content:
[img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/How-the-military.webp" caption="Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth arrives before President Donald Trump speaks on his first 100 days at Macomb County Community College Sports Expo Center in Warren, Mich."]
The military services scrambled Friday to nail down details and put together new guidance to start removing transgender troops from the force.

Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, in a memo released late Thursday, reinstated orders issued earlier this year that said ‚Äúexpressing a false gender identity divergent from an individual's sex cannot satisfy the rigorous standards necessary for military service."

His new order gives active duty troops until June 6 to identify themselves as transgender and voluntarily begin to leave the service. National Guard and Reserve troops have until July 7.

Army Maj. Alivia Stehlik, who served in the infantry and is now a physical therapist, will be eligible to retire in three years but doesn‚Äôt want to be forced out for being a transgender service member.

‚ÄúI still have a job to do,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúMy command expects me to show up and be an officer and do my job because I‚Äôm the only person at my unit who can do what I do.‚Äù

The military services were rushing to put out new guidance to help commanders work through the process, including what to do in more complex situations, such as if any of the troops are deployed, at sea or may require special orders or funding to meet the deadlines.

There are about 2.1 million active duty, Guard and Reserve troops.

According to the Defense Department, about 1,000 service members have voluntarily identified themselves as transgender and will now begin the process of leaving the military. And while the totals are early estimates, as many as 500 of those are Army soldiers, hundreds are in the Navy and at least 50 are Marines.

DCu42x33wUy9ouM0NKtx.title: Immigrants disappear from US detainee tracking system after deportation flights
DCu42x33wUy9ouM0NKtx.summary: The comments reflect a broad range of perspectives on illegal immigration, particularly regarding the situation of Venezuelan migrants. The majority voice emphasizes the humanitarian aspect, advocating for compassion towards migrants and stressing the need for due process and acknowledgment of their difficult circumstances. In contrast, the minority of commenters argue that illegal immigration should not be tolerated, asserting that individuals who enter the U.S. unlawfully should face deportation and highlighting concerns about their impact on American resources.
DCu42x33wUy9ouM0NKtx.content: [img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Immigrants-disappear-from.webp" caption="This undated photo provided by Johanny Sanchez shows Sanchez, right, and her husband Franco Caraballo, who was sent over the weekend to El Salvador accused by the Trump administration of belonging to the Venezuelan Tren de Aragua gang."] Franco Caraballo called his wife Friday night, crying and panicked. Hours earlier, the 26-year-old barber and dozens of other Venezuelan migrants at a federal detention facility in Texas were dressed in white clothes, handcuffed and taken onto a plane. He had no idea where he was going. Twenty-four hours later, Caraballo‚Äôs name disappeared from the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement‚Äôs online detainee locator. On Monday, his wife, Johanny S√°nchez, learned Caraballo was among more than 200 Venezuelan immigrants flown over the weekend to El Salvador, where they are in a maximum-security prison after being accused by the Trump administration of belonging to the Venezuelan Tren de Aragua gang. S√°nchez insists her husband isn't a gang member. She struggles even to find logic in the accusation. The weekend flights Flights by U.S. immigration authorities set off a frantic scramble among terrified families after hundreds of immigrants vanished from ICE‚Äôs online locator. Some turned up at that massive El Salvador prison, where visitors, recreation and education are not allowed. The U.S. has paid El Salvador's government $6 million to hold immigrants, many of them Venezuelan, whose government rarely accepts deportees from the U.S. But many families have no idea where to find their loved ones. El Salvador has no online database to look up inmates, and families there often struggle to get information. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know anything about my son,‚Äù said Xiomara Vizcaya, a 46-year-old Venezuelan. On Saturday, President Donald Trump announced he had invoked the Alien Enemies Act of 1798, which allows the U.S. to deport noncitizens without any legal recourse, including rights to appear before an immigration or federal court judge. Many conservatives have cheered the deportations and the Trump administration for taking a hard stance on immigration. The Venezuelan government has called the flights ‚Äúkidnappings.‚Äù It urged its citizens living in the U.S. to return home and vowed get others back from El Salvador. But with diplomatic ties long broken between Venezuela and El Salvador, the prisoners have few advocates. The U.S. deportations exacerbate Venezuela‚Äôs immigration crisis by turning ‚Äúmigrants into geopolitical pawns,‚Äù said Oscar Murillo, head of the Venezuelan human rights group Provea. "There is a lack of transparency on the part of the U.S. and El Salvador regarding the status of deported individuals and the crimes for which they are being prosecuted.‚Äù S√°nchez is among those who believes the American dream has turned ugly. She wants to leave the U.S. once she finds her husband. ‚ÄúWe fled Venezuela for a better future. We never imagined things would be worse.‚Äù

F74KCtbWv6f4Wtb4Yhnm.title: Immigrants disappear from US detainee tracking system after deportation flights
F74KCtbWv6f4Wtb4Yhnm.summary: The comments reflect a broad range of perspectives on illegal immigration, particularly regarding the situation of Venezuelan migrants. The majority of commenters argue that illegal immigration should not be tolerated, asserting that individuals who enter the U.S. unlawfully should face deportation and highlighting concerns about their impact on American resources. In contrast, the minority voice emphasizes the humanitarian aspect, advocating for compassion towards migrants and stressing the need for due process and acknowledgment of their difficult circumstances.
F74KCtbWv6f4Wtb4Yhnm.content: [img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Immigrants-disappear-from.webp" caption="This undated photo provided by Johanny Sanchez shows Sanchez, right, and her husband Franco Caraballo, who was sent over the weekend to El Salvador accused by the Trump administration of belonging to the Venezuelan Tren de Aragua gang."] Franco Caraballo called his wife Friday night, crying and panicked. Hours earlier, the 26-year-old barber and dozens of other Venezuelan migrants at a federal detention facility in Texas were dressed in white clothes, handcuffed and taken onto a plane. He had no idea where he was going. Twenty-four hours later, Caraballo‚Äôs name disappeared from the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement‚Äôs online detainee locator. On Monday, his wife, Johanny S√°nchez, learned Caraballo was among more than 200 Venezuelan immigrants flown over the weekend to El Salvador, where they are in a maximum-security prison after being accused by the Trump administration of belonging to the Venezuelan Tren de Aragua gang. S√°nchez insists her husband isn't a gang member. She struggles even to find logic in the accusation. The weekend flights Flights by U.S. immigration authorities set off a frantic scramble among terrified families after hundreds of immigrants vanished from ICE‚Äôs online locator. Some turned up at that massive El Salvador prison, where visitors, recreation and education are not allowed. The U.S. has paid El Salvador's government $6 million to hold immigrants, many of them Venezuelan, whose government rarely accepts deportees from the U.S. But many families have no idea where to find their loved ones. El Salvador has no online database to look up inmates, and families there often struggle to get information. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know anything about my son,‚Äù said Xiomara Vizcaya, a 46-year-old Venezuelan. On Saturday, President Donald Trump announced he had invoked the Alien Enemies Act of 1798, which allows the U.S. to deport noncitizens without any legal recourse, including rights to appear before an immigration or federal court judge. Many conservatives have cheered the deportations and the Trump administration for taking a hard stance on immigration. The Venezuelan government has called the flights ‚Äúkidnappings.‚Äù It urged its citizens living in the U.S. to return home and vowed get others back from El Salvador. But with diplomatic ties long broken between Venezuela and El Salvador, the prisoners have few advocates. The U.S. deportations exacerbate Venezuela‚Äôs immigration crisis by turning ‚Äúmigrants into geopolitical pawns,‚Äù said Oscar Murillo, head of the Venezuelan human rights group Provea. "There is a lack of transparency on the part of the U.S. and El Salvador regarding the status of deported individuals and the crimes for which they are being prosecuted.‚Äù S√°nchez is among those who believes the American dream has turned ugly. She wants to leave the U.S. once she finds her husband. ‚ÄúWe fled Venezuela for a better future. We never imagined things would be worse.‚Äù

HC73Fzud6pgBpfj3pjED.title: How the military is dealing with Hegseth's order to remove transgender troops
HC73Fzud6pgBpfj3pjED.summary: The comments present a broad range of perspectives on the issue of transgender rights and recognition. A majority of comments express pro-transgender views, emphasizing the importance of inclusivity and acceptance for transgender individuals. Conversely, a minority of comments express anti-transgender sentiments, questioning the validity of gender identity and advocating for traditional definitions of gender.
HC73Fzud6pgBpfj3pjED.content:
[img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/How-the-military.webp" caption="Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth arrives before President Donald Trump speaks on his first 100 days at Macomb County Community College Sports Expo Center in Warren, Mich."]
The military services scrambled Friday to nail down details and put together new guidance to start removing transgender troops from the force.

Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, in a memo released late Thursday, reinstated orders issued earlier this year that said ‚Äúexpressing a false gender identity divergent from an individual's sex cannot satisfy the rigorous standards necessary for military service."

His new order gives active duty troops until June 6 to identify themselves as transgender and voluntarily begin to leave the service. National Guard and Reserve troops have until July 7.

Army Maj. Alivia Stehlik, who served in the infantry and is now a physical therapist, will be eligible to retire in three years but doesn‚Äôt want to be forced out for being a transgender service member.

‚ÄúI still have a job to do,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúMy command expects me to show up and be an officer and do my job because I‚Äôm the only person at my unit who can do what I do.‚Äù

The military services were rushing to put out new guidance to help commanders work through the process, including what to do in more complex situations, such as if any of the troops are deployed, at sea or may require special orders or funding to meet the deadlines.

There are about 2.1 million active duty, Guard and Reserve troops.

According to the Defense Department, about 1,000 service members have voluntarily identified themselves as transgender and will now begin the process of leaving the military. And while the totals are early estimates, as many as 500 of those are Army soldiers, hundreds are in the Navy and at least 50 are Marines.

JPOPdnRv1ERbFObpZS6c.summary: The comments reflect a broad range of perspectives on illegal immigration, particularly regarding the situation of Venezuelan migrants. The majority voice emphasizes the humanitarian aspect, advocating for compassion towards migrants and stressing the need for due process and acknowledgment of their difficult circumstances. In contrast, the minority of commenters argue that illegal immigration should not be tolerated, asserting that individuals who enter the U.S. unlawfully should face deportation and highlighting concerns about their impact on American resources.
JPOPdnRv1ERbFObpZS6c.title: Immigrants disappear from US detainee tracking system after deportation flights
JPOPdnRv1ERbFObpZS6c.content: [img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Immigrants-disappear-from.webp" caption="This undated photo provided by Johanny Sanchez shows Sanchez, right, and her husband Franco Caraballo, who was sent over the weekend to El Salvador accused by the Trump administration of belonging to the Venezuelan Tren de Aragua gang."] Franco Caraballo called his wife Friday night, crying and panicked. Hours earlier, the 26-year-old barber and dozens of other Venezuelan migrants at a federal detention facility in Texas were dressed in white clothes, handcuffed and taken onto a plane. He had no idea where he was going. Twenty-four hours later, Caraballo‚Äôs name disappeared from the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement‚Äôs online detainee locator. On Monday, his wife, Johanny S√°nchez, learned Caraballo was among more than 200 Venezuelan immigrants flown over the weekend to El Salvador, where they are in a maximum-security prison after being accused by the Trump administration of belonging to the Venezuelan Tren de Aragua gang. S√°nchez insists her husband isn't a gang member. She struggles even to find logic in the accusation. The weekend flights Flights by U.S. immigration authorities set off a frantic scramble among terrified families after hundreds of immigrants vanished from ICE‚Äôs online locator. Some turned up at that massive El Salvador prison, where visitors, recreation and education are not allowed. The U.S. has paid El Salvador's government $6 million to hold immigrants, many of them Venezuelan, whose government rarely accepts deportees from the U.S. But many families have no idea where to find their loved ones. El Salvador has no online database to look up inmates, and families there often struggle to get information. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know anything about my son,‚Äù said Xiomara Vizcaya, a 46-year-old Venezuelan. On Saturday, President Donald Trump announced he had invoked the Alien Enemies Act of 1798, which allows the U.S. to deport noncitizens without any legal recourse, including rights to appear before an immigration or federal court judge. Many conservatives have cheered the deportations and the Trump administration for taking a hard stance on immigration. The Venezuelan government has called the flights ‚Äúkidnappings.‚Äù It urged its citizens living in the U.S. to return home and vowed get others back from El Salvador. But with diplomatic ties long broken between Venezuela and El Salvador, the prisoners have few advocates. The U.S. deportations exacerbate Venezuela‚Äôs immigration crisis by turning ‚Äúmigrants into geopolitical pawns,‚Äù said Oscar Murillo, head of the Venezuelan human rights group Provea. "There is a lack of transparency on the part of the U.S. and El Salvador regarding the status of deported individuals and the crimes for which they are being prosecuted.‚Äù S√°nchez is among those who believes the American dream has turned ugly. She wants to leave the U.S. once she finds her husband. ‚ÄúWe fled Venezuela for a better future. We never imagined things would be worse.‚Äù

M3wd81Jhi5VpVDAiblpo.title: Women's March Downtown Calls for Reproductive Rights
M3wd81Jhi5VpVDAiblpo.content:
Samantha Ripple was tattooed with a single word‚Äî‚ÄúJUSTICE‚Äù‚Äîas she marched with about 500 people through the streets of Indianapolis on Saturday in the latest Women‚Äôs March to demand reproductive rights and access to safe, legal abortions.

‚ÄúI came out because reproductive rights are human rights,‚Äù said Ripple, 22.

Ripple was one of the three demonstrators charged with disturbing the peace, Indianapolis police said. They were accused of violating a city noise ordinance by using megaphones without a permit. Also charged were Michelle Johnson, 72, and Suzann Brown, 45.

‚ÄúWe have to make our voices heard,‚Äù said Johnson, ‚ÄúThe Supreme Court is trying to control our bodies, which violates our constitutional rights.‚Äù

The march is one of thousands of demonstrations that have swept the nation after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, which had protected a constitutional right to abortion since 1973. These marches are part of a groundswell of grassroots activism fighting for reproductive rights and asking for states to protect access to abortion.

After the Court decision, a number of Republican-led states, mostly in the South and Midwest, implemented laws banning or restricting abortions, while many Democrat-led states have moved forward with measures to protect abortion access. According to the White House, almost 30 million women of reproductive age live in states with an ongoing abortion ban.

Johnson recalled that before Roe v. Wade, her close friend nearly bled to death in a sorority house because she was afraid she could get arrested if she sought an illegal abortion.

‚ÄúI am marching for my friends and others like her,‚Äù Johnson said.

Brown said she has marched in a half dozen rallies for abortion rights since Roe was overturned. She became pregnant at age 15. ‚ÄúI agonized about whether to have an abortion,‚Äù said Brown, who ultimately put her baby up for adoption. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm marching because I can‚Äôt imagine not having a choice at that time.‚Äù

‚ÄúEverybody has the right to their own body,‚Äù Brown said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not up to anyone else.‚Äù

McAsEOb3Mno4IdtFZeQV.title: Immigrants disappear from US detainee tracking system after deportation flights
McAsEOb3Mno4IdtFZeQV.content: [img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Immigrants-disappear-from.webp" caption="This undated photo provided by Johanny Sanchez shows Sanchez, right, and her husband Franco Caraballo, who was sent over the weekend to El Salvador accused by the Trump administration of belonging to the Venezuelan Tren de Aragua gang."] Franco Caraballo called his wife Friday night, crying and panicked. Hours earlier, the 26-year-old barber and dozens of other Venezuelan migrants at a federal detention facility in Texas were dressed in white clothes, handcuffed and taken onto a plane. He had no idea where he was going. Twenty-four hours later, Caraballo‚Äôs name disappeared from the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement‚Äôs online detainee locator. On Monday, his wife, Johanny S√°nchez, learned Caraballo was among more than 200 Venezuelan immigrants flown over the weekend to El Salvador, where they are in a maximum-security prison after being accused by the Trump administration of belonging to the Venezuelan Tren de Aragua gang. S√°nchez insists her husband isn't a gang member. She struggles even to find logic in the accusation. The weekend flights Flights by U.S. immigration authorities set off a frantic scramble among terrified families after hundreds of immigrants vanished from ICE‚Äôs online locator. Some turned up at that massive El Salvador prison, where visitors, recreation and education are not allowed. The U.S. has paid El Salvador's government $6 million to hold immigrants, many of them Venezuelan, whose government rarely accepts deportees from the U.S. But many families have no idea where to find their loved ones. El Salvador has no online database to look up inmates, and families there often struggle to get information. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know anything about my son,‚Äù said Xiomara Vizcaya, a 46-year-old Venezuelan. On Saturday, President Donald Trump announced he had invoked the Alien Enemies Act of 1798, which allows the U.S. to deport noncitizens without any legal recourse, including rights to appear before an immigration or federal court judge. Many conservatives have cheered the deportations and the Trump administration for taking a hard stance on immigration. The Venezuelan government has called the flights ‚Äúkidnappings.‚Äù It urged its citizens living in the U.S. to return home and vowed get others back from El Salvador. But with diplomatic ties long broken between Venezuela and El Salvador, the prisoners have few advocates. The U.S. deportations exacerbate Venezuela‚Äôs immigration crisis by turning ‚Äúmigrants into geopolitical pawns,‚Äù said Oscar Murillo, head of the Venezuelan human rights group Provea. "There is a lack of transparency on the part of the U.S. and El Salvador regarding the status of deported individuals and the crimes for which they are being prosecuted.‚Äù S√°nchez is among those who believes the American dream has turned ugly. She wants to leave the U.S. once she finds her husband. ‚ÄúWe fled Venezuela for a better future. We never imagined things would be worse.‚Äù

UJtRNtmpdrtQqydLH7TG.title: Supreme Court throws out appellate rulings in favor of transgender people in 4 states
UJtRNtmpdrtQqydLH7TG.content:
[img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Supreme-Court-throws.webp" caption="FILE - Transgenders rights supporters rally outside of the Supreme Court in Washington."]
The Supreme Court on Monday threw out appellate rulings in favor of transgender people in four states following the justices' recent decision upholding a Tennessee ban on certain medical treatment for transgender youths.

But the justices took no action in cases from Arizona, Idaho and West Virginia involving the participation of transgender students on school sports teams. The court could say as soon as Thursday whether it will take up the issue in its next term.

The high court ordered appellate judges to reexamine cases from Idaho, North Carolina, Oklahoma and West Virginia involving access to medical care and birth certificates.

The action was unsurprising because the court had set the cases aside until after it decided the Tennessee case, as typically happens when the same legal issue is being considered.

The rulings all included findings that the restrictions on transgender people imposed by the states violate the Constitution's equal protection clause.

In the Tennessee case, the Supreme Court ruled that there was no constitutional violation in a state law prohibiting puberty blockers and hormone therapy to treat gender dysphoria in people younger than 18.

The justices ordered the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Richmond, Virginia, to review its decision that West Virginia‚Äôs and North Carolina‚Äôs refusal to cover certain health care for transgender people with government-sponsored insurance is discriminatory.

The San Francisco-based 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals will get back a case from Idaho stemming from the state's ban on certain surgical procedures for Medicaid recipients.

The 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Denver will review its ruling blocking an Oklahoma ban on people changing their gender on birth certificates.

In one other case, from Kentucky, the justices rejected the appeal of transgender minors and their families challenging that state‚Äôs ban on gender-affirming care.
UJtRNtmpdrtQqydLH7TG.summary: The comments present a broad range of perspectives on transgender issues. The majority expresses pro-transgender views, advocating for acceptance and equality for transgender individuals. Conversely, a minority voices anti-transgender sentiments, emphasizing concerns about gender identity and its implications.

Vc3oi0qzzgF0cVbhLCXP.title: Supreme Court throws out appellate rulings in favor of transgender people in 4 states
Vc3oi0qzzgF0cVbhLCXP.content:
[img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Supreme-Court-throws.webp" caption="FILE - Transgenders rights supporters rally outside of the Supreme Court in Washington."]
The Supreme Court on Monday threw out appellate rulings in favor of transgender people in four states following the justices' recent decision upholding a Tennessee ban on certain medical treatment for transgender youths.

But the justices took no action in cases from Arizona, Idaho and West Virginia involving the participation of transgender students on school sports teams. The court could say as soon as Thursday whether it will take up the issue in its next term.

The high court ordered appellate judges to reexamine cases from Idaho, North Carolina, Oklahoma and West Virginia involving access to medical care and birth certificates.

The action was unsurprising because the court had set the cases aside until after it decided the Tennessee case, as typically happens when the same legal issue is being considered.

The rulings all included findings that the restrictions on transgender people imposed by the states violate the Constitution's equal protection clause.

In the Tennessee case, the Supreme Court ruled that there was no constitutional violation in a state law prohibiting puberty blockers and hormone therapy to treat gender dysphoria in people younger than 18.

The justices ordered the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Richmond, Virginia, to review its decision that West Virginia‚Äôs and North Carolina‚Äôs refusal to cover certain health care for transgender people with government-sponsored insurance is discriminatory.

The San Francisco-based 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals will get back a case from Idaho stemming from the state's ban on certain surgical procedures for Medicaid recipients.

The 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Denver will review its ruling blocking an Oklahoma ban on people changing their gender on birth certificates.

In one other case, from Kentucky, the justices rejected the appeal of transgender minors and their families challenging that state‚Äôs ban on gender-affirming care.

VrCebUdbz58lXd0fZ0GL.title: How the military is dealing with Hegseth's order to remove transgender troops
VrCebUdbz58lXd0fZ0GL.summary: The comments present a broad range of perspectives on the issue of transgender rights and recognition. A majority of comments express pro-transgender views, emphasizing the importance of inclusivity and acceptance for transgender individuals. Conversely, a minority of comments express anti-transgender sentiments, questioning the validity of gender identity and advocating for traditional definitions of gender.
VrCebUdbz58lXd0fZ0GL.content:
[img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/How-the-military.webp" caption="Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth arrives before President Donald Trump speaks on his first 100 days at Macomb County Community College Sports Expo Center in Warren, Mich."]
The military services scrambled Friday to nail down details and put together new guidance to start removing transgender troops from the force.

Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, in a memo released late Thursday, reinstated orders issued earlier this year that said ‚Äúexpressing a false gender identity divergent from an individual's sex cannot satisfy the rigorous standards necessary for military service."

His new order gives active duty troops until June 6 to identify themselves as transgender and voluntarily begin to leave the service. National Guard and Reserve troops have until July 7.

Army Maj. Alivia Stehlik, who served in the infantry and is now a physical therapist, will be eligible to retire in three years but doesn‚Äôt want to be forced out for being a transgender service member.

‚ÄúI still have a job to do,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúMy command expects me to show up and be an officer and do my job because I‚Äôm the only person at my unit who can do what I do.‚Äù

The military services were rushing to put out new guidance to help commanders work through the process, including what to do in more complex situations, such as if any of the troops are deployed, at sea or may require special orders or funding to meet the deadlines.

There are about 2.1 million active duty, Guard and Reserve troops.

According to the Defense Department, about 1,000 service members have voluntarily identified themselves as transgender and will now begin the process of leaving the military. And while the totals are early estimates, as many as 500 of those are Army soldiers, hundreds are in the Navy and at least 50 are Marines.

XL2EhwGqCbwzc0eCatlH.title: How the military is dealing with Hegseth's order to remove transgender troops
XL2EhwGqCbwzc0eCatlH.content:
[img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/How-the-military.webp" caption="Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth arrives before President Donald Trump speaks on his first 100 days at Macomb County Community College Sports Expo Center in Warren, Mich."]
The military services scrambled Friday to nail down details and put together new guidance to start removing transgender troops from the force.

Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, in a memo released late Thursday, reinstated orders issued earlier this year that said ‚Äúexpressing a false gender identity divergent from an individual's sex cannot satisfy the rigorous standards necessary for military service."

His new order gives active duty troops until June 6 to identify themselves as transgender and voluntarily begin to leave the service. National Guard and Reserve troops have until July 7.

Army Maj. Alivia Stehlik, who served in the infantry and is now a physical therapist, will be eligible to retire in three years but doesn‚Äôt want to be forced out for being a transgender service member.

‚ÄúI still have a job to do,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúMy command expects me to show up and be an officer and do my job because I‚Äôm the only person at my unit who can do what I do.‚Äù

The military services were rushing to put out new guidance to help commanders work through the process, including what to do in more complex situations, such as if any of the troops are deployed, at sea or may require special orders or funding to meet the deadlines.

There are about 2.1 million active duty, Guard and Reserve troops.

According to the Defense Department, about 1,000 service members have voluntarily identified themselves as transgender and will now begin the process of leaving the military. And while the totals are early estimates, as many as 500 of those are Army soldiers, hundreds are in the Navy and at least 50 are Marines.

aGiEUTUWB6oCHZ4Qlluw.title: Volunteers use bullhorns and sirens to warn immigrants when ICE is in their area
aGiEUTUWB6oCHZ4Qlluw.summary: The comments present a broad range of perspectives regarding immigration enforcement, particularly the actions of volunteers who warn undocumented immigrants of ICE operations. A majority of commenters argue for the compassion and rights of immigrants, suggesting that aiding those seeking better lives shouldn't be criminalized and is akin to exercising free speech. Conversely, a minority of commentators express strong support for strict immigration control, advocating for the arrest and prosecution of those perceived to be aiding undocumented immigrants by warning them of ICE activities, viewing this as criminal conduct tantamount to obstruction of justice.
aGiEUTUWB6oCHZ4Qlluw.content:
[img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Volunteers-use-bullhorns.webp" caption="Ron Gochez, a teacher volunteering with Union del Barrio, an organization advocating for immigrant rights, is reflected in a side mirror as he searches for ICE activity in a neighborhood in Los Angeles."]
Just before dawn, 10 people met at a parking lot shared by a laundromat and coffee shop in South Central Los Angeles on what has become a daily mission: Look for immigration officers and warn people of their presence to try to prevent arrests. Bullhorns and sirens are ready for use. 

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs raza that‚Äôs been detained,‚Äù Ron Gochez, founder of Union del Barrio's Los Angeles chapter, said before they split up in five cars. ‚ÄúIt seems like there‚Äôs more activity now. Let‚Äôs keep a close eye out.‚Äù 

Working with other similar-size groups and using walkie-talkies, the Community Self-Defense Coalition, made up of more than 60 organizations, found nothing Thursday but appeared to have disrupted U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement operations earlier in the week. In Los Angeles and across the country, these tactics have been a thorn in ICE's side as it tries to carry out President Donald Trump's promise of mass deportations. 

Counter-ICE operations have had ‚Äúa huge impact,‚Äù said John Fabbricatore, a former head of ICE's enforcement and removal division in Denver. 

‚ÄúIt's dangerous for the officers because they are trying to get into a situation, maybe undercover, trying to make an arrest without alarming the neighborhood, and then these guys come out here with these bullhorns and they start yelling and screaming,‚Äù Fabbricatore said. 

Advocates ‚Äúgo right to the edge‚Äù of a law against impeding federal law enforcement to avoid criminal prosecution, he said. 

Advocates say they are exercising free speech and reminding people of their rights. ICE officers cannot forcibly enter a home without a judicial warrant, which they rarely have. Sophisticated ‚Äúknow-your- rights‚Äù campaigns urge people to stay inside and not open the door. 

Back at the parking lot about two hours after Thursday's mission started, the city was waking up. On the corner, a street vendor had set up her tamales stand. 

‚ÄúWe just got a report right now that all of our patrols happening in San Diego, Escondido, California; Los Angeles, California; South Gate and Alhambra, everything is all clear right now,‚Äù said Gochez, before heading to his day job as a high school history teacher.

aUpN8DvS34Kr8AMCRAGN.title: Supreme Court throws out appellate rulings in favor of transgender people in 4 states
aUpN8DvS34Kr8AMCRAGN.content:
[img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Supreme-Court-throws.webp" caption="FILE - Transgenders rights supporters rally outside of the Supreme Court in Washington."]
The Supreme Court on Monday threw out appellate rulings in favor of transgender people in four states following the justices' recent decision upholding a Tennessee ban on certain medical treatment for transgender youths.

But the justices took no action in cases from Arizona, Idaho and West Virginia involving the participation of transgender students on school sports teams. The court could say as soon as Thursday whether it will take up the issue in its next term.

The high court ordered appellate judges to reexamine cases from Idaho, North Carolina, Oklahoma and West Virginia involving access to medical care and birth certificates.

The action was unsurprising because the court had set the cases aside until after it decided the Tennessee case, as typically happens when the same legal issue is being considered.

The rulings all included findings that the restrictions on transgender people imposed by the states violate the Constitution's equal protection clause.

In the Tennessee case, the Supreme Court ruled that there was no constitutional violation in a state law prohibiting puberty blockers and hormone therapy to treat gender dysphoria in people younger than 18.

The justices ordered the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Richmond, Virginia, to review its decision that West Virginia‚Äôs and North Carolina‚Äôs refusal to cover certain health care for transgender people with government-sponsored insurance is discriminatory.

The San Francisco-based 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals will get back a case from Idaho stemming from the state's ban on certain surgical procedures for Medicaid recipients.

The 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Denver will review its ruling blocking an Oklahoma ban on people changing their gender on birth certificates.

In one other case, from Kentucky, the justices rejected the appeal of transgender minors and their families challenging that state‚Äôs ban on gender-affirming care.

aVuD2neHVVArfVf11bbS.title: Immigrants disappear from US detainee tracking system after deportation flights
aVuD2neHVVArfVf11bbS.content: [img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Immigrants-disappear-from.webp" caption="This undated photo provided by Johanny Sanchez shows Sanchez, right, and her husband Franco Caraballo, who was sent over the weekend to El Salvador accused by the Trump administration of belonging to the Venezuelan Tren de Aragua gang."] Franco Caraballo called his wife Friday night, crying and panicked. Hours earlier, the 26-year-old barber and dozens of other Venezuelan migrants at a federal detention facility in Texas were dressed in white clothes, handcuffed and taken onto a plane. He had no idea where he was going. Twenty-four hours later, Caraballo‚Äôs name disappeared from the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement‚Äôs online detainee locator. On Monday, his wife, Johanny S√°nchez, learned Caraballo was among more than 200 Venezuelan immigrants flown over the weekend to El Salvador, where they are in a maximum-security prison after being accused by the Trump administration of belonging to the Venezuelan Tren de Aragua gang. S√°nchez insists her husband isn't a gang member. She struggles even to find logic in the accusation. The weekend flights Flights by U.S. immigration authorities set off a frantic scramble among terrified families after hundreds of immigrants vanished from ICE‚Äôs online locator. Some turned up at that massive El Salvador prison, where visitors, recreation and education are not allowed. The U.S. has paid El Salvador's government $6 million to hold immigrants, many of them Venezuelan, whose government rarely accepts deportees from the U.S. But many families have no idea where to find their loved ones. El Salvador has no online database to look up inmates, and families there often struggle to get information. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know anything about my son,‚Äù said Xiomara Vizcaya, a 46-year-old Venezuelan. On Saturday, President Donald Trump announced he had invoked the Alien Enemies Act of 1798, which allows the U.S. to deport noncitizens without any legal recourse, including rights to appear before an immigration or federal court judge. Many conservatives have cheered the deportations and the Trump administration for taking a hard stance on immigration. The Venezuelan government has called the flights ‚Äúkidnappings.‚Äù It urged its citizens living in the U.S. to return home and vowed get others back from El Salvador. But with diplomatic ties long broken between Venezuela and El Salvador, the prisoners have few advocates. The U.S. deportations exacerbate Venezuela‚Äôs immigration crisis by turning ‚Äúmigrants into geopolitical pawns,‚Äù said Oscar Murillo, head of the Venezuelan human rights group Provea. "There is a lack of transparency on the part of the U.S. and El Salvador regarding the status of deported individuals and the crimes for which they are being prosecuted.‚Äù S√°nchez is among those who believes the American dream has turned ugly. She wants to leave the U.S. once she finds her husband. ‚ÄúWe fled Venezuela for a better future. We never imagined things would be worse.‚Äù

c2hSXhgPsq4mxCarsp8a.title: Volunteers use bullhorns and sirens to warn immigrants when ICE is in their area
c2hSXhgPsq4mxCarsp8a.content:
[img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Volunteers-use-bullhorns.webp" caption="Ron Gochez, a teacher volunteering with Union del Barrio, an organization advocating for immigrant rights, is reflected in a side mirror as he searches for ICE activity in a neighborhood in Los Angeles."]
Just before dawn, 10 people met at a parking lot shared by a laundromat and coffee shop in South Central Los Angeles on what has become a daily mission: Look for immigration officers and warn people of their presence to try to prevent arrests. Bullhorns and sirens are ready for use. 

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs raza that‚Äôs been detained,‚Äù Ron Gochez, founder of Union del Barrio's Los Angeles chapter, said before they split up in five cars. ‚ÄúIt seems like there‚Äôs more activity now. Let‚Äôs keep a close eye out.‚Äù 

Working with other similar-size groups and using walkie-talkies, the Community Self-Defense Coalition, made up of more than 60 organizations, found nothing Thursday but appeared to have disrupted U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement operations earlier in the week. In Los Angeles and across the country, these tactics have been a thorn in ICE's side as it tries to carry out President Donald Trump's promise of mass deportations. 

Counter-ICE operations have had ‚Äúa huge impact,‚Äù said John Fabbricatore, a former head of ICE's enforcement and removal division in Denver. 

‚ÄúIt's dangerous for the officers because they are trying to get into a situation, maybe undercover, trying to make an arrest without alarming the neighborhood, and then these guys come out here with these bullhorns and they start yelling and screaming,‚Äù Fabbricatore said. 

Advocates ‚Äúgo right to the edge‚Äù of a law against impeding federal law enforcement to avoid criminal prosecution, he said. 

Advocates say they are exercising free speech and reminding people of their rights. ICE officers cannot forcibly enter a home without a judicial warrant, which they rarely have. Sophisticated ‚Äúknow-your- rights‚Äù campaigns urge people to stay inside and not open the door. 

Back at the parking lot about two hours after Thursday's mission started, the city was waking up. On the corner, a street vendor had set up her tamales stand. 

‚ÄúWe just got a report right now that all of our patrols happening in San Diego, Escondido, California; Los Angeles, California; South Gate and Alhambra, everything is all clear right now,‚Äù said Gochez, before heading to his day job as a high school history teacher.

eVLqjCGNrg6YDbAWhz1l.title: How the military is dealing with Hegseth's order to remove transgender troops
eVLqjCGNrg6YDbAWhz1l.summary: The comments present a broad range of perspectives on the issue of transgender rights and recognition. A majority of comments express anti-transgender sentiments, questioning the validity of gender identity and advocating for traditional definitions of gender. Conversely, a minority of comments express pro-transgender views, emphasizing the importance of inclusivity and acceptance for transgender individuals.
eVLqjCGNrg6YDbAWhz1l.content:
[img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/How-the-military.webp" caption="Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth arrives before President Donald Trump speaks on his first 100 days at Macomb County Community College Sports Expo Center in Warren, Mich."]
The military services scrambled Friday to nail down details and put together new guidance to start removing transgender troops from the force.

Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, in a memo released late Thursday, reinstated orders issued earlier this year that said ‚Äúexpressing a false gender identity divergent from an individual's sex cannot satisfy the rigorous standards necessary for military service."

His new order gives active duty troops until June 6 to identify themselves as transgender and voluntarily begin to leave the service. National Guard and Reserve troops have until July 7.

Army Maj. Alivia Stehlik, who served in the infantry and is now a physical therapist, will be eligible to retire in three years but doesn‚Äôt want to be forced out for being a transgender service member.

‚ÄúI still have a job to do,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúMy command expects me to show up and be an officer and do my job because I‚Äôm the only person at my unit who can do what I do.‚Äù

The military services were rushing to put out new guidance to help commanders work through the process, including what to do in more complex situations, such as if any of the troops are deployed, at sea or may require special orders or funding to meet the deadlines.

There are about 2.1 million active duty, Guard and Reserve troops.

According to the Defense Department, about 1,000 service members have voluntarily identified themselves as transgender and will now begin the process of leaving the military. And while the totals are early estimates, as many as 500 of those are Army soldiers, hundreds are in the Navy and at least 50 are Marines.

ixkLil9HtBnvU5H9E7zD.title: Volunteers use bullhorns and sirens to warn immigrants when ICE is in their area
ixkLil9HtBnvU5H9E7zD.content:
[img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Volunteers-use-bullhorns.webp" caption="Ron Gochez, a teacher volunteering with Union del Barrio, an organization advocating for immigrant rights, is reflected in a side mirror as he searches for ICE activity in a neighborhood in Los Angeles."]
Just before dawn, 10 people met at a parking lot shared by a laundromat and coffee shop in South Central Los Angeles on what has become a daily mission: Look for immigration officers and warn people of their presence to try to prevent arrests. Bullhorns and sirens are ready for use. 

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs raza that‚Äôs been detained,‚Äù Ron Gochez, founder of Union del Barrio's Los Angeles chapter, said before they split up in five cars. ‚ÄúIt seems like there‚Äôs more activity now. Let‚Äôs keep a close eye out.‚Äù 

Working with other similar-size groups and using walkie-talkies, the Community Self-Defense Coalition, made up of more than 60 organizations, found nothing Thursday but appeared to have disrupted U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement operations earlier in the week. In Los Angeles and across the country, these tactics have been a thorn in ICE's side as it tries to carry out President Donald Trump's promise of mass deportations. 

Counter-ICE operations have had ‚Äúa huge impact,‚Äù said John Fabbricatore, a former head of ICE's enforcement and removal division in Denver. 

‚ÄúIt's dangerous for the officers because they are trying to get into a situation, maybe undercover, trying to make an arrest without alarming the neighborhood, and then these guys come out here with these bullhorns and they start yelling and screaming,‚Äù Fabbricatore said. 

Advocates ‚Äúgo right to the edge‚Äù of a law against impeding federal law enforcement to avoid criminal prosecution, he said. 

Advocates say they are exercising free speech and reminding people of their rights. ICE officers cannot forcibly enter a home without a judicial warrant, which they rarely have. Sophisticated ‚Äúknow-your- rights‚Äù campaigns urge people to stay inside and not open the door. 

Back at the parking lot about two hours after Thursday's mission started, the city was waking up. On the corner, a street vendor had set up her tamales stand. 

‚ÄúWe just got a report right now that all of our patrols happening in San Diego, Escondido, California; Los Angeles, California; South Gate and Alhambra, everything is all clear right now,‚Äù said Gochez, before heading to his day job as a high school history teacher.

kYHCTx6cEUDNgs5QDCBD.title: Volunteers use bullhorns and sirens to warn immigrants when ICE is in their area
kYHCTx6cEUDNgs5QDCBD.content:
[img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Volunteers-use-bullhorns.webp" caption="Ron Gochez, a teacher volunteering with Union del Barrio, an organization advocating for immigrant rights, is reflected in a side mirror as he searches for ICE activity in a neighborhood in Los Angeles."]
Just before dawn, 10 people met at a parking lot shared by a laundromat and coffee shop in South Central Los Angeles on what has become a daily mission: Look for immigration officers and warn people of their presence to try to prevent arrests. Bullhorns and sirens are ready for use. 

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs raza that‚Äôs been detained,‚Äù Ron Gochez, founder of Union del Barrio's Los Angeles chapter, said before they split up in five cars. ‚ÄúIt seems like there‚Äôs more activity now. Let‚Äôs keep a close eye out.‚Äù 

Working with other similar-size groups and using walkie-talkies, the Community Self-Defense Coalition, made up of more than 60 organizations, found nothing Thursday but appeared to have disrupted U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement operations earlier in the week. In Los Angeles and across the country, these tactics have been a thorn in ICE's side as it tries to carry out President Donald Trump's promise of mass deportations. 

Counter-ICE operations have had ‚Äúa huge impact,‚Äù said John Fabbricatore, a former head of ICE's enforcement and removal division in Denver. 

‚ÄúIt's dangerous for the officers because they are trying to get into a situation, maybe undercover, trying to make an arrest without alarming the neighborhood, and then these guys come out here with these bullhorns and they start yelling and screaming,‚Äù Fabbricatore said. 

Advocates ‚Äúgo right to the edge‚Äù of a law against impeding federal law enforcement to avoid criminal prosecution, he said. 

Advocates say they are exercising free speech and reminding people of their rights. ICE officers cannot forcibly enter a home without a judicial warrant, which they rarely have. Sophisticated ‚Äúknow-your- rights‚Äù campaigns urge people to stay inside and not open the door. 

Back at the parking lot about two hours after Thursday's mission started, the city was waking up. On the corner, a street vendor had set up her tamales stand. 

‚ÄúWe just got a report right now that all of our patrols happening in San Diego, Escondido, California; Los Angeles, California; South Gate and Alhambra, everything is all clear right now,‚Äù said Gochez, before heading to his day job as a high school history teacher.

mxuyXZXoJ73Vbj9aHCUo.title: Volunteers use bullhorns and sirens to warn immigrants when ICE is in their area
mxuyXZXoJ73Vbj9aHCUo.summary: The comments present a broad range of perspectives regarding immigration enforcement, particularly the actions of volunteers who warn undocumented immigrants of ICE operations. A majority of commenters argue for the compassion and rights of immigrants, suggesting that aiding those seeking better lives shouldn't be criminalized and is akin to exercising free speech. Conversely, a minority of commentators express strong support for strict immigration control, advocating for the arrest and prosecution of those perceived to be aiding undocumented immigrants by warning them of ICE activities, viewing this as criminal conduct tantamount to obstruction of justice.
mxuyXZXoJ73Vbj9aHCUo.content:
[img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Volunteers-use-bullhorns.webp" caption="Ron Gochez, a teacher volunteering with Union del Barrio, an organization advocating for immigrant rights, is reflected in a side mirror as he searches for ICE activity in a neighborhood in Los Angeles."]
Just before dawn, 10 people met at a parking lot shared by a laundromat and coffee shop in South Central Los Angeles on what has become a daily mission: Look for immigration officers and warn people of their presence to try to prevent arrests. Bullhorns and sirens are ready for use. 

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs raza that‚Äôs been detained,‚Äù Ron Gochez, founder of Union del Barrio's Los Angeles chapter, said before they split up in five cars. ‚ÄúIt seems like there‚Äôs more activity now. Let‚Äôs keep a close eye out.‚Äù 

Working with other similar-size groups and using walkie-talkies, the Community Self-Defense Coalition, made up of more than 60 organizations, found nothing Thursday but appeared to have disrupted U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement operations earlier in the week. In Los Angeles and across the country, these tactics have been a thorn in ICE's side as it tries to carry out President Donald Trump's promise of mass deportations. 

Counter-ICE operations have had ‚Äúa huge impact,‚Äù said John Fabbricatore, a former head of ICE's enforcement and removal division in Denver. 

‚ÄúIt's dangerous for the officers because they are trying to get into a situation, maybe undercover, trying to make an arrest without alarming the neighborhood, and then these guys come out here with these bullhorns and they start yelling and screaming,‚Äù Fabbricatore said. 

Advocates ‚Äúgo right to the edge‚Äù of a law against impeding federal law enforcement to avoid criminal prosecution, he said. 

Advocates say they are exercising free speech and reminding people of their rights. ICE officers cannot forcibly enter a home without a judicial warrant, which they rarely have. Sophisticated ‚Äúknow-your- rights‚Äù campaigns urge people to stay inside and not open the door. 

Back at the parking lot about two hours after Thursday's mission started, the city was waking up. On the corner, a street vendor had set up her tamales stand. 

‚ÄúWe just got a report right now that all of our patrols happening in San Diego, Escondido, California; Los Angeles, California; South Gate and Alhambra, everything is all clear right now,‚Äù said Gochez, before heading to his day job as a high school history teacher.

n2fzCZpSPlSu19rGZjkJ.title: How the military is dealing with Hegseth's order to remove transgender troops
n2fzCZpSPlSu19rGZjkJ.summary: The comments present a broad range of perspectives on the issue of transgender rights and recognition. A majority of comments express anti-transgender sentiments, questioning the validity of gender identity and advocating for traditional definitions of gender. Conversely, a minority of comments express pro-transgender views, emphasizing the importance of inclusivity and acceptance for transgender individuals.
n2fzCZpSPlSu19rGZjkJ.content:
[img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/How-the-military.webp" caption="Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth arrives before President Donald Trump speaks on his first 100 days at Macomb County Community College Sports Expo Center in Warren, Mich."]
The military services scrambled Friday to nail down details and put together new guidance to start removing transgender troops from the force.

Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, in a memo released late Thursday, reinstated orders issued earlier this year that said ‚Äúexpressing a false gender identity divergent from an individual's sex cannot satisfy the rigorous standards necessary for military service."

His new order gives active duty troops until June 6 to identify themselves as transgender and voluntarily begin to leave the service. National Guard and Reserve troops have until July 7.

Army Maj. Alivia Stehlik, who served in the infantry and is now a physical therapist, will be eligible to retire in three years but doesn‚Äôt want to be forced out for being a transgender service member.

‚ÄúI still have a job to do,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúMy command expects me to show up and be an officer and do my job because I‚Äôm the only person at my unit who can do what I do.‚Äù

The military services were rushing to put out new guidance to help commanders work through the process, including what to do in more complex situations, such as if any of the troops are deployed, at sea or may require special orders or funding to meet the deadlines.

There are about 2.1 million active duty, Guard and Reserve troops.

According to the Defense Department, about 1,000 service members have voluntarily identified themselves as transgender and will now begin the process of leaving the military. And while the totals are early estimates, as many as 500 of those are Army soldiers, hundreds are in the Navy and at least 50 are Marines.

oCJfBHQ9UilQ7RUjspFc.title: Supreme Court throws out appellate rulings in favor of transgender people in 4 states
oCJfBHQ9UilQ7RUjspFc.content:
[img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Supreme-Court-throws.webp" caption="FILE - Transgenders rights supporters rally outside of the Supreme Court in Washington."]
The Supreme Court on Monday threw out appellate rulings in favor of transgender people in four states following the justices' recent decision upholding a Tennessee ban on certain medical treatment for transgender youths.

But the justices took no action in cases from Arizona, Idaho and West Virginia involving the participation of transgender students on school sports teams. The court could say as soon as Thursday whether it will take up the issue in its next term.

The high court ordered appellate judges to reexamine cases from Idaho, North Carolina, Oklahoma and West Virginia involving access to medical care and birth certificates.

The action was unsurprising because the court had set the cases aside until after it decided the Tennessee case, as typically happens when the same legal issue is being considered.

The rulings all included findings that the restrictions on transgender people imposed by the states violate the Constitution's equal protection clause.

In the Tennessee case, the Supreme Court ruled that there was no constitutional violation in a state law prohibiting puberty blockers and hormone therapy to treat gender dysphoria in people younger than 18.

The justices ordered the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Richmond, Virginia, to review its decision that West Virginia‚Äôs and North Carolina‚Äôs refusal to cover certain health care for transgender people with government-sponsored insurance is discriminatory.

The San Francisco-based 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals will get back a case from Idaho stemming from the state's ban on certain surgical procedures for Medicaid recipients.

The 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Denver will review its ruling blocking an Oklahoma ban on people changing their gender on birth certificates.

In one other case, from Kentucky, the justices rejected the appeal of transgender minors and their families challenging that state‚Äôs ban on gender-affirming care.

default_comments.content: None of these procedures should ever be legal to be performed on minors. And none of these procedures should ever be paid by insurance for any adult. qSVrOlDxzgl2alcHEuuJ.title: Supreme Court throws out appellate rulings in favor of transgender people in 4 states
qSVrOlDxzgl2alcHEuuJ.content:
[img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Supreme-Court-throws.webp" caption="FILE - Transgenders rights supporters rally outside of the Supreme Court in Washington."]
The Supreme Court on Monday threw out appellate rulings in favor of transgender people in four states following the justices' recent decision upholding a Tennessee ban on certain medical treatment for transgender youths.

But the justices took no action in cases from Arizona, Idaho and West Virginia involving the participation of transgender students on school sports teams. The court could say as soon as Thursday whether it will take up the issue in its next term.

The high court ordered appellate judges to reexamine cases from Idaho, North Carolina, Oklahoma and West Virginia involving access to medical care and birth certificates.

The action was unsurprising because the court had set the cases aside until after it decided the Tennessee case, as typically happens when the same legal issue is being considered.

The rulings all included findings that the restrictions on transgender people imposed by the states violate the Constitution's equal protection clause.

In the Tennessee case, the Supreme Court ruled that there was no constitutional violation in a state law prohibiting puberty blockers and hormone therapy to treat gender dysphoria in people younger than 18.

The justices ordered the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Richmond, Virginia, to review its decision that West Virginia‚Äôs and North Carolina‚Äôs refusal to cover certain health care for transgender people with government-sponsored insurance is discriminatory.

The San Francisco-based 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals will get back a case from Idaho stemming from the state's ban on certain surgical procedures for Medicaid recipients.

The 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Denver will review its ruling blocking an Oklahoma ban on people changing their gender on birth certificates.

In one other case, from Kentucky, the justices rejected the appeal of transgender minors and their families challenging that state‚Äôs ban on gender-affirming care.

qZYcUcD8zI0BTRr9jZHH.title: Supreme Court throws out appellate rulings in favor of transgender people in 4 states
qZYcUcD8zI0BTRr9jZHH.content:
[img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Supreme-Court-throws.webp" caption="FILE - Transgenders rights supporters rally outside of the Supreme Court in Washington."]
The Supreme Court on Monday threw out appellate rulings in favor of transgender people in four states following the justices' recent decision upholding a Tennessee ban on certain medical treatment for transgender youths.

But the justices took no action in cases from Arizona, Idaho and West Virginia involving the participation of transgender students on school sports teams. The court could say as soon as Thursday whether it will take up the issue in its next term.

The high court ordered appellate judges to reexamine cases from Idaho, North Carolina, Oklahoma and West Virginia involving access to medical care and birth certificates.

The action was unsurprising because the court had set the cases aside until after it decided the Tennessee case, as typically happens when the same legal issue is being considered.

The rulings all included findings that the restrictions on transgender people imposed by the states violate the Constitution's equal protection clause.

In the Tennessee case, the Supreme Court ruled that there was no constitutional violation in a state law prohibiting puberty blockers and hormone therapy to treat gender dysphoria in people younger than 18.

The justices ordered the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Richmond, Virginia, to review its decision that West Virginia‚Äôs and North Carolina‚Äôs refusal to cover certain health care for transgender people with government-sponsored insurance is discriminatory.

The San Francisco-based 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals will get back a case from Idaho stemming from the state's ban on certain surgical procedures for Medicaid recipients.

The 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Denver will review its ruling blocking an Oklahoma ban on people changing their gender on birth certificates.

In one other case, from Kentucky, the justices rejected the appeal of transgender minors and their families challenging that state‚Äôs ban on gender-affirming care.

qwrbXVje6v87H0rrt2PY.title: Volunteers use bullhorns and sirens to warn immigrants when ICE is in their area
qwrbXVje6v87H0rrt2PY.content:
[img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Volunteers-use-bullhorns.webp" caption="Ron Gochez, a teacher volunteering with Union del Barrio, an organization advocating for immigrant rights, is reflected in a side mirror as he searches for ICE activity in a neighborhood in Los Angeles."]
Just before dawn, 10 people met at a parking lot shared by a laundromat and coffee shop in South Central Los Angeles on what has become a daily mission: Look for immigration officers and warn people of their presence to try to prevent arrests. Bullhorns and sirens are ready for use. 

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs raza that‚Äôs been detained,‚Äù Ron Gochez, founder of Union del Barrio's Los Angeles chapter, said before they split up in five cars. ‚ÄúIt seems like there‚Äôs more activity now. Let‚Äôs keep a close eye out.‚Äù 

Working with other similar-size groups and using walkie-talkies, the Community Self-Defense Coalition, made up of more than 60 organizations, found nothing Thursday but appeared to have disrupted U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement operations earlier in the week. In Los Angeles and across the country, these tactics have been a thorn in ICE's side as it tries to carry out President Donald Trump's promise of mass deportations. 

Counter-ICE operations have had ‚Äúa huge impact,‚Äù said John Fabbricatore, a former head of ICE's enforcement and removal division in Denver. 

‚ÄúIt's dangerous for the officers because they are trying to get into a situation, maybe undercover, trying to make an arrest without alarming the neighborhood, and then these guys come out here with these bullhorns and they start yelling and screaming,‚Äù Fabbricatore said. 

Advocates ‚Äúgo right to the edge‚Äù of a law against impeding federal law enforcement to avoid criminal prosecution, he said. 

Advocates say they are exercising free speech and reminding people of their rights. ICE officers cannot forcibly enter a home without a judicial warrant, which they rarely have. Sophisticated ‚Äúknow-your- rights‚Äù campaigns urge people to stay inside and not open the door. 

Back at the parking lot about two hours after Thursday's mission started, the city was waking up. On the corner, a street vendor had set up her tamales stand. 

‚ÄúWe just got a report right now that all of our patrols happening in San Diego, Escondido, California; Los Angeles, California; South Gate and Alhambra, everything is all clear right now,‚Äù said Gochez, before heading to his day job as a high school history teacher.
