rYC2kCYhhei8Q2vrpicA.title: Immigrants disappear from US detainee tracking system after deportation flights
rYC2kCYhhei8Q2vrpicA.summary: The comments reflect a broad range of perspectives on illegal immigration, particularly regarding the situation of Venezuelan migrants. The majority of commenters argue that illegal immigration should not be tolerated, asserting that individuals who enter the U.S. unlawfully should face deportation and highlighting concerns about their impact on American resources. In contrast, the minority voice emphasizes the humanitarian aspect, advocating for compassion towards migrants and stressing the need for due process and acknowledgment of their difficult circumstances.
rYC2kCYhhei8Q2vrpicA.content: [img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Immigrants-disappear-from.webp" caption="This undated photo provided by Johanny Sanchez shows Sanchez, right, and her husband Franco Caraballo, who was sent over the weekend to El Salvador accused by the Trump administration of belonging to the Venezuelan Tren de Aragua gang."] Franco Caraballo called his wife Friday night, crying and panicked. Hours earlier, the 26-year-old barber and dozens of other Venezuelan migrants at a federal detention facility in Texas were dressed in white clothes, handcuffed and taken onto a plane. He had no idea where he was going. Twenty-four hours later, Caraballo‚Äôs name disappeared from the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement‚Äôs online detainee locator. On Monday, his wife, Johanny S√°nchez, learned Caraballo was among more than 200 Venezuelan immigrants flown over the weekend to El Salvador, where they are in a maximum-security prison after being accused by the Trump administration of belonging to the Venezuelan Tren de Aragua gang. S√°nchez insists her husband isn't a gang member. She struggles even to find logic in the accusation. The weekend flights Flights by U.S. immigration authorities set off a frantic scramble among terrified families after hundreds of immigrants vanished from ICE‚Äôs online locator. Some turned up at that massive El Salvador prison, where visitors, recreation and education are not allowed. The U.S. has paid El Salvador's government $6 million to hold immigrants, many of them Venezuelan, whose government rarely accepts deportees from the U.S. But many families have no idea where to find their loved ones. El Salvador has no online database to look up inmates, and families there often struggle to get information. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know anything about my son,‚Äù said Xiomara Vizcaya, a 46-year-old Venezuelan. On Saturday, President Donald Trump announced he had invoked the Alien Enemies Act of 1798, which allows the U.S. to deport noncitizens without any legal recourse, including rights to appear before an immigration or federal court judge. Many conservatives have cheered the deportations and the Trump administration for taking a hard stance on immigration. The Venezuelan government has called the flights ‚Äúkidnappings.‚Äù It urged its citizens living in the U.S. to return home and vowed get others back from El Salvador. But with diplomatic ties long broken between Venezuela and El Salvador, the prisoners have few advocates. The U.S. deportations exacerbate Venezuela‚Äôs immigration crisis by turning ‚Äúmigrants into geopolitical pawns,‚Äù said Oscar Murillo, head of the Venezuelan human rights group Provea. "There is a lack of transparency on the part of the U.S. and El Salvador regarding the status of deported individuals and the crimes for which they are being prosecuted.‚Äù S√°nchez is among those who believes the American dream has turned ugly. She wants to leave the U.S. once she finds her husband. ‚ÄúWe fled Venezuela for a better future. We never imagined things would be worse.‚Äù

rtqQuXXcoHj272NImZPm.title: Immigrants disappear from US detainee tracking system after deportation flights
rtqQuXXcoHj272NImZPm.content: [img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Immigrants-disappear-from.webp" caption="This undated photo provided by Johanny Sanchez shows Sanchez, right, and her husband Franco Caraballo, who was sent over the weekend to El Salvador accused by the Trump administration of belonging to the Venezuelan Tren de Aragua gang."] Franco Caraballo called his wife Friday night, crying and panicked. Hours earlier, the 26-year-old barber and dozens of other Venezuelan migrants at a federal detention facility in Texas were dressed in white clothes, handcuffed and taken onto a plane. He had no idea where he was going. Twenty-four hours later, Caraballo‚Äôs name disappeared from the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement‚Äôs online detainee locator. On Monday, his wife, Johanny S√°nchez, learned Caraballo was among more than 200 Venezuelan immigrants flown over the weekend to El Salvador, where they are in a maximum-security prison after being accused by the Trump administration of belonging to the Venezuelan Tren de Aragua gang. S√°nchez insists her husband isn't a gang member. She struggles even to find logic in the accusation. The weekend flights Flights by U.S. immigration authorities set off a frantic scramble among terrified families after hundreds of immigrants vanished from ICE‚Äôs online locator. Some turned up at that massive El Salvador prison, where visitors, recreation and education are not allowed. The U.S. has paid El Salvador's government $6 million to hold immigrants, many of them Venezuelan, whose government rarely accepts deportees from the U.S. But many families have no idea where to find their loved ones. El Salvador has no online database to look up inmates, and families there often struggle to get information. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know anything about my son,‚Äù said Xiomara Vizcaya, a 46-year-old Venezuelan. On Saturday, President Donald Trump announced he had invoked the Alien Enemies Act of 1798, which allows the U.S. to deport noncitizens without any legal recourse, including rights to appear before an immigration or federal court judge. Many conservatives have cheered the deportations and the Trump administration for taking a hard stance on immigration. The Venezuelan government has called the flights ‚Äúkidnappings.‚Äù It urged its citizens living in the U.S. to return home and vowed get others back from El Salvador. But with diplomatic ties long broken between Venezuela and El Salvador, the prisoners have few advocates. The U.S. deportations exacerbate Venezuela‚Äôs immigration crisis by turning ‚Äúmigrants into geopolitical pawns,‚Äù said Oscar Murillo, head of the Venezuelan human rights group Provea. "There is a lack of transparency on the part of the U.S. and El Salvador regarding the status of deported individuals and the crimes for which they are being prosecuted.‚Äù S√°nchez is among those who believes the American dream has turned ugly. She wants to leave the U.S. once she finds her husband. ‚ÄúWe fled Venezuela for a better future. We never imagined things would be worse.‚Äù

s1z2C65JPdK0J2aP1r8y.title: How the military is dealing with Hegseth's order to remove transgender troops
s1z2C65JPdK0J2aP1r8y.content:
[img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/How-the-military.webp" caption="Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth arrives before President Donald Trump speaks on his first 100 days at Macomb County Community College Sports Expo Center in Warren, Mich."]
The military services scrambled Friday to nail down details and put together new guidance to start removing transgender troops from the force.

Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, in a memo released late Thursday, reinstated orders issued earlier this year that said ‚Äúexpressing a false gender identity divergent from an individual's sex cannot satisfy the rigorous standards necessary for military service."

His new order gives active duty troops until June 6 to identify themselves as transgender and voluntarily begin to leave the service. National Guard and Reserve troops have until July 7.

Army Maj. Alivia Stehlik, who served in the infantry and is now a physical therapist, will be eligible to retire in three years but doesn‚Äôt want to be forced out for being a transgender service member.

‚ÄúI still have a job to do,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúMy command expects me to show up and be an officer and do my job because I‚Äôm the only person at my unit who can do what I do.‚Äù

The military services were rushing to put out new guidance to help commanders work through the process, including what to do in more complex situations, such as if any of the troops are deployed, at sea or may require special orders or funding to meet the deadlines.

There are about 2.1 million active duty, Guard and Reserve troops.

According to the Defense Department, about 1,000 service members have voluntarily identified themselves as transgender and will now begin the process of leaving the military. And while the totals are early estimates, as many as 500 of those are Army soldiers, hundreds are in the Navy and at least 50 are Marines.

skrbvQanfhSFA8jjaMqt.title: Volunteers use bullhorns and sirens to warn immigrants when ICE is in their area
skrbvQanfhSFA8jjaMqt.summary: The comments present a broad range of perspectives regarding immigration enforcement, particularly the actions of volunteers who warn undocumented immigrants of ICE operations. A majority of commenters express strong support for strict immigration control, advocating for the arrest and prosecution of those perceived to be aiding undocumented immigrants by warning them of ICE activities, viewing this as criminal conduct tantamount to obstruction of justice. Conversely, a minority of commentators argue for the compassion and rights of immigrants, suggesting that aiding those seeking better lives shouldn't be criminalized and is akin to exercising free speech.
skrbvQanfhSFA8jjaMqt.content:
[img src="https://mediaengagement.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/Volunteers-use-bullhorns.webp" caption="Ron Gochez, a teacher volunteering with Union del Barrio, an organization advocating for immigrant rights, is reflected in a side mirror as he searches for ICE activity in a neighborhood in Los Angeles."]
Just before dawn, 10 people met at a parking lot shared by a laundromat and coffee shop in South Central Los Angeles on what has become a daily mission: Look for immigration officers and warn people of their presence to try to prevent arrests. Bullhorns and sirens are ready for use. 

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs raza that‚Äôs been detained,‚Äù Ron Gochez, founder of Union del Barrio's Los Angeles chapter, said before they split up in five cars. ‚ÄúIt seems like there‚Äôs more activity now. Let‚Äôs keep a close eye out.‚Äù 

Working with other similar-size groups and using walkie-talkies, the Community Self-Defense Coalition, made up of more than 60 organizations, found nothing Thursday but appeared to have disrupted U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement operations earlier in the week. In Los Angeles and across the country, these tactics have been a thorn in ICE's side as it tries to carry out President Donald Trump's promise of mass deportations. 

Counter-ICE operations have had ‚Äúa huge impact,‚Äù said John Fabbricatore, a former head of ICE's enforcement and removal division in Denver. 

‚ÄúIt's dangerous for the officers because they are trying to get into a situation, maybe undercover, trying to make an arrest without alarming the neighborhood, and then these guys come out here with these bullhorns and they start yelling and screaming,‚Äù Fabbricatore said. 

Advocates ‚Äúgo right to the edge‚Äù of a law against impeding federal law enforcement to avoid criminal prosecution, he said. 

Advocates say they are exercising free speech and reminding people of their rights. ICE officers cannot forcibly enter a home without a judicial warrant, which they rarely have. Sophisticated ‚Äúknow-your- rights‚Äù campaigns urge people to stay inside and not open the door. 

Back at the parking lot about two hours after Thursday's mission started, the city was waking up. On the corner, a street vendor had set up her tamales stand. 

‚ÄúWe just got a report right now that all of our patrols happening in San Diego, Escondido, California; Los Angeles, California; South Gate and Alhambra, everything is all clear right now,‚Äù said Gochez, before heading to his day job as a high school history teacher.
